questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? (NEET PG 2022)

 

  1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
  2. Baby on artificial feeds
  3. Baby of working mother/single parent
  4. Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
  5. Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Among the given options, babies on artificial feeds and babies of working/single parents are considered at-risk babies.

 

 

It is important to identify children at risk and give special intensive care. This is done because these children contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants on artificial feeding or with a working/single parent are at risk and require intensive care to prevent perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.

questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

 

Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate back to glucose. It is activated when the insulin-to-glucagon ratio decreases. This enzyme plays a crucial role in gluconeogenesis, the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources when blood glucose levels are low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucokinase: Glucokinase is an enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is primarily found in the liver and pancreatic beta cells. Glucokinase's activity is influenced by glucose levels, not the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Option B. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is another enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is present in various tissues, but its activity is not directly regulated by changes in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio's

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate. It plays a role in glucose metabolism but is not activated by a decrease in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, which occurs during fasting.
  • Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state.
  • Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin.
  • Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Immunoglobulins

 

Explanation

 

Immunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells.

 

Essentially all the albumin and fibrinogen of the plasma proteins, as well as 50 to 80 per cent of the globulins, are formed in the liver. The remainder of the globulins are formed almost entirely in the lymphoid tissues. They are mainly the gamma globulins that constitute the antibodies used in the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Exclusion, as albumin is a major protein synthesized by the liver, which is the most abundant protein in plasma, playing crucial roles in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances such as drugs and hormones.

 

Option B. Coagulation factors: Exclusion, as these are primarily produced by the liver, including factors such as prothrombin and fibrinogen.

 

Option C. Acute phase proteins: Exclusion, as the liver significantly ramps up production of these proteins in response to inflammation or infection (like C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA), which play roles in modulating the immune response and inflammation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

 

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: Which of the following lipid storage disorder presents with Cherry Red Spot in Macula? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach's disease

 

Tay Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder that characteristically presents with a cherry-red spot in the macula. This appearance is due to the accumulation of gangliosides in the retinal ganglion cells, causing the macula to appear pale and contrasting with the normal red color of the fovea, creating the cherry-red spot appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's disease: While it may cause pseudo cherry-red spot and not a true cherry-red spot in ophthalmology.

 

Option C. Krabbe's disease: This is a leukodystrophy that primarily affects the nervous system but does not typically cause a cherry-red spot in the macula.

 

Option D. Fabry's disease: While this condition can affect the eyes, it typically causes corneal verticillata (corneal whorls) rather than a cherry-red spot in the macula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cherry-red spot in the macula is a characteristic finding in several lipid storage disorders, with Tay Sachs disease being the most notable.

 

The mnemonic "BeE STING" can be helpful in remembering causes of cherry-red spot: Berlin's Edema, Sclerosis, Tay-Sachs, Ischemia (CRAO), Niemann-Pick, and GM1 Gangliosidosis.

questions.text: For Health Education, the Motivation Model has its 1st  Step as Awareness. Its 2nd  Step is Motivation. Its 3rd  Step is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Action

 

The Motivation Model for Health Education comprises three steps:

 

  1. Awareness: This step involves generating interest in the person’s mind about the health topic or problem.
  2. Motivation: This stage includes evaluation and decision-making, where the person is encouraged and motivated to consider the health information or behavior change.
  3. Action: This is the final step where the individual accepts and adopts the health idea or practice. The person moves from motivation to implementation, engaging in the recommended health behavior.

 

Other 2 Models are –

 

  • Medical Model – This involves interaction between the patient and doctor, where the patient presents their illness, and the doctor diagnoses it as a disease.
  • Social Interactive Model

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dedication: Dedication is not explicitly a step in the Motivation Model but can be an outcome of sustained action and commitment to the behavior change.

 

Option C. Contemplation: Contemplation is a stage in other health behavior change models, such as the Transtheoretical Model, where individuals consider changing but do not yet take action. It is not the third step in the Motivation Model.

 

Option D. Reflection: Reflection is not part of the Motivation Model’s steps. It typically refers to thinking back on actions and decisions, often occurring after the behavior has been implemented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The third step in the Motivation Model for Health Education is Action, which signifies the adoption and implementation of the health behavior.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure that involves the removal of a small segment of the lactiferous duct, typically from the breast in which a probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made, and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. This procedure is known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Microdochectomy

 

  • Microdochectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing a discharging lactiferous duct.
  • The procedure is typically performed on patients with duct papilloma or duct ectasia involving a single duct.
  • During the procedure, a probe or stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging.
  • An incision can be made in the shape of a tennis racquet to encompass the entire duct, or a periareolar incision may be used to access the duct by dissecting the nipple flap.
  • The affected duct is then excised or removed, and the tissue is sent for further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrodochectomy: Macrodochectomy refers to the removal of a larger or major segment of the lactiferous duct. This procedure can be undertaken when there are multiple pathologies within the duct, making it necessary to excise a more substantial portion of the duct system.

 

Option C. Cone excision: In breast surgery, it might mean the removal of a cone-shaped segment of tissue which includes a problematic area, such as a localized tumor. The goal is often to ensure that the margins of the removed tissue are clear of any pathological changes.

 

Option D. Wide excision of the lactiferous duct: This procedure involves removing a more extensive portion of the lactiferous duct, typically more than in a microdochectomy. The objective here might be to ensure that the entirety of a problematic duct or surrounding tissue is removed, especially if there is a concern about a larger segment of the duct being involved with a disease process.

 

Educational Objective:


Microdochectomy is the surgical removal of a discharging lactiferous duct, commonly performed for cases of single-duct pathologies like duct papilloma or duct ectasia.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted during which kind of examination in court? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross examination 

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by an attorney, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Examination-in-chief: Leading questions are generally not allowed during examination-in-chief to prevent the lawyer from influencing the witness's testimony.

 

Option B. Direct examination: Similar to examination-in-chief, direct examination aims to elicit the witness's own account without leading questions.

 

Option D. Re-direct examination: Leading questions are also not allowed in re-direct examination, as the purpose is to clarify or rebut points raised during cross-examination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in: 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in: 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin presented with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. The finding of the ultrasound is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

The given clinical situation and USG showing enlarged ovaries having large cysts points to diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

 

OVARIAN HYPERSTIMULATION SYNDROME

 

  • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • The clinical features appear about 3–6 days after the ovulating dose of hCG is administered.
  • Pathophysiology - Increased capillary permeability leads to leakage of fluid from the peritoneal and ovarian surfaces. Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines, Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines.

 

 

 

Management - The management of OHSS is mainly supportive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycystic ovarian syndrome: PCOS is characterized by chronic anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries, but it does not typically present with sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness associated with enlarged ovaries having large cysts as seen in OHSS.

 

Option C. Theca lutein cysts: These cysts are associated with molar pregnancies and multiple gestations, often presenting with high levels of hCG but not typically with the acute symptoms and clinical scenario described here.

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: This is a type of ovarian tumor that does not present with the acute symptoms and ultrasound findings characteristic of OHSS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation, with symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness, often visible on ultrasound as enlarged ovaries with large cysts.

questions.text: Paris green powder is used for killing of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anopheles larva

 

Paris green powder is a chemical compound known as copper acetoarsenate, which is used as an anti-larval agent in the control of mosquito populations, under National Vector Borne Disease Control Program, India.

 

The mechanism of action of Paris green is that it acts as a stomach poison when ingested by the larvae. This disrupts the normal biological functions of the larvae, effectively killing them before they can mature into adult mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria parasite: Paris green powder does not target the malaria parasite directly. Instead, it targets the mosquito larvae, which are vectors for the parasite.

 

Option C. Mites: Paris green powder is not effective against mites; it is specifically used against mosquito larvae.

 

Option D. Adult mosquito: While there are chemical agents such as DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion that are used to target adult mosquitoes. These adulticides work as nerve or contact poisons, inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme in adult mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antilarval measures: Paris green – 2% dust applied in dose of 1 kg per hectare; ‘stomach poison’ to larvae but harmless to humans, animals or fish

 

Antiadult measures: DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: Obturator Sign in Acute Appendicitis is most commonly associated with which appendix position? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pelvic Appendix

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator sign is elicited when the examiner flexes the patient's right hip and knee and then internally rotates the hip, causing pain in the hypogastrium. This sign is positive when an inflamed appendix lies in contact with the obturator internus muscle. The pelvic position of the appendix places it directly adjacent to the obturator internus muscle, making this sign characteristic of pelvic appendicitis. When the obturator muscle contracts during internal rotation of the hip, it irritates the inflamed appendix, producing pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrocecal - This position places the appendix behind the cecum against the psoas muscle, typically resulting in a positive psoas sign (pain on extension of the hip) rather than obturator sign. Retrocecal appendicitis often presents with flank or back pain.

 

Option C. Pre-Ileal - When the appendix lies anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically produces classic right lower quadrant pain at McBurney's point without specific muscle signs.

 

Option D. Post-Ileal - In this position, the appendix lies behind the ileum but not necessarily in contact with the obturator muscle, making the obturator sign unlikely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The obturator sign indicates irritation of the obturator internus muscle by an inflamed appendix, most commonly occurring when the appendix is in the pelvic position, and serves as an important physical examination finding for identifying atypical appendicitis.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.

 

Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.

 

Staging of CA Cervix

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prader-Willi syndrome

 

The image represents chromosome 15, showing a deletion specifically on the paternal chromosome. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a segment on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13.

 

This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, hyperphagia leading to obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and distinct physical features.

 

Prader-Willi syndrome can also occur due to maternal uniparental disomy (Maternal UPD), where two copies of the maternal chromosome are present, and no paternal copy is active.

 

These two mechanisms—paternal deletion and maternal uniparental disomy—are the main causes of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

In rare cases, an issue with imprinting itself can also lead to the syndrome, but the primary focus is on the two causes mentioned.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angelman syndrome: Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It presents with severe intellectual disability, ataxia, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent smiling and laughter, which differs from Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option C. VHL syndrome: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with mutations on chromosome 3, leading to various tumors, including hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It is unrelated to chromosome 15 deletions.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is a chromosomal disorder caused by an extra chromosome 18, presenting with severe intellectual disability, heart defects, and characteristic physical anomalies. It does not involve deletions on chromosome 15.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by maternal uniparental disomy, and is characterized by obesity due to hyperphagia, intellectual disability, and specific behavioral traits.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

questions.text: Which of the following is not controlled by Kilovolt Peak (kVp) in X-ray imaging? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Density

 

Explanation: 

 

Kilovolt Peak (kVp) regulates the velocity of electrons traveling from cathode to anode in the X-ray tube. KVp determines the quality and quantity of X-rays and affects penetration. The relationship is expressed as "kVp ∝ penetration" and "kVp ∝ 1/contrast." Density (film blackening) is controlled by mAs (milliamperage second), not by kVp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast - This is incorrect because kVp does control contrast. KVp is inversely proportional to contrast. When kVp increases, contrast decreases.

 

Option B. Penetrating Power - This is incorrect because kVp does control penetration. KVp is directly proportional to penetration. Higher kVp increases the X-ray beam's ability to penetrate tissue.

 

Option D. Quality - This is incorrect because kVp does determine the quality of X-rays. KVp affects the energy spectrum of the X-ray beam produced.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

KVp controls the X-ray beam's energy (quality), penetration ability, and contrast, while mAs controls the quantity of X-rays and thus the radiographic density (blackening) of films.

questions.text: Which of the following solid organ transplants have the highest chance of GVHD (graft versus host disease)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intestine

 

Explanation

 

Graft versus host disease (GVHD) is most commonly associated with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, particularly allogeneic transplants. However, GVHD can also occur following solid organ transplants.

 

GVHD occurs when donor immune cells attack the recipient's tissues.

 

The intestine has the highest risk of GVHD among solid organ transplants due to the presence of abundant lymphoid tissue, including Peyer's patches, which contain many donor lymphocytes capable of attacking the recipient’s body.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Kidney: While kidney transplants can result in immune complications, the risk of GVHD is significantly lower compared to intestinal transplants.

 

Option B. Liver: The liver has a moderate risk of GVHD but not as high as the intestine.

 

Option D. Heart: The heart has a lower risk of GVHD compared to the intestine.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The intestine is the solid organ transplant with the highest risk of graft versus host disease due to the presence of lymphoid tissue containing donor lymphocytes.

questions.text: A patient presents with linear nodular lesions extending along the lymphatic drainage after sustaining a rose thorn injury. Examination reveals a chain of linear subcutaneous granulomas. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

A history of a rose thorn prick followed by linear subcutaneous granulomas is highly suggestive of Sporotrichosis also known as "rose gardener's disease."which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. This is a dimorphic fungus commonly associated with gardening injuries, particularly from rose thorns. The infection typically follows a lymphocutaneous spread, forming a chain of nodules along lymphatic drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: Characterized by chronic verrucous skin lesions and copper-colored sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) in tissue, typically due to traumatic implantation of fungi.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Causes cutaneous or pulmonary nocardiosis, which often presents with abscess formation but does not follow a linear spread along lymphatics.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Causes Blastomycosis, a systemic fungal infection that primarily affects the lungs and disseminates to the skin and bones but does not present with lymphocutaneous nodular spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is a subcutaneous fungal infection commonly acquired through traumatic inoculation, such as a rose thorn prick. It presents as lymphocutaneous nodular lesions that spread along lymphatics in a linear pattern. Diagnosis is confirmed by culture on Sabouraud’s agar, and treatment is typically oral itraconazole for mild cases or amphotericin B for severe infections.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG displays a rhythm with broad QRS complexes at a high rate, consistent with ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT is characterized by three or more consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of more than 100 beats per minute. The presence of such a pattern, particularly with a stable, repetitive form as seen in the ECG, strongly points to VT rather than other types of arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ECG: This option is incorrect as the ECG clearly shows an abnormal rhythm with broad QRS complexes, indicative of an arrhythmia originating below the AV node.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by irregular, chaotic electrical activity without identifiable QRS complexes, P waves, or T waves. The rhythm shown here is too organized and regular to be VF.

 

Option D. Misplaced leads: Misplaced leads causes positive p in aVR with normal intervals - R wave progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular tachycardia is identified by regular, broad QRS complexes at a rapid rate, distinct from the irregular pattern of ventricular fibrillation and the organized, narrower complexes typically seen with supraventricular rhythms and correct lead placement. Identifying VT on an ECG is critical due to its potential severity and the need for prompt treatment.

questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to the hospital with blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nifedipine

 

Explanation

 

In managing hypertension in a pregnant patient with a history of bronchial asthma, the choice of antihypertensive medication is critical due to the contraindications of certain drug classes in both pregnancy and asthma.

 

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is considered safe in pregnancy and does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it the preferred choice for hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with asthma.

 

Nicardipine, another calcium channel blocker, can also be used, especially in IV form, but nifedipine is often chosen due to its safety profile and efficacy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Oral Labetalol and Option C. IV Labetalol: Contraindicated in asthma due to bronchoconstriction. These drugs can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction, making them unsuitable for patients with asthma.

 

Option D. Ramipril: ACE inhibitors like Ramipril are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal toxicity, including renal damage and oligohydramnios

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with bronchial asthma, nifedipine is the preferred drug due to its safety in pregnancy and lack of bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is undergoing chronic medication therapy for a long-term condition. The healthcare team wants to maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug. What formula should be used to calculate the maintenance dose rate of the drug for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clearance x Plasma concentration

 

The formula for the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is generally expressed as:

 

Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL) × Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp) 

 

This formula aims to achieve a steady-state concentration of the drug in the bloodstream. By multiplying the clearance rate by the desired plasma concentration, you get the rate at which the drug should be administered to maintain that desired concentration.

 

Note –

 

The loading dose is designed to quickly achieve the desired therapeutic level, whereas the maintenance dose sustains that level over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula for calculating the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is:

 

Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL)×Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp)

 

This formula is used to achieve and maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug

questions.text: All are the members of the medical board in MTP > 24 weeks, except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Legal advisor

 

For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks, especially in cases of substantial fetal anomalies, a medical board is constituted. This board typically includes specialists relevant to the condition and the required medical care. The standard members include: Radiologist, Gynecologist and Pediatrician.

 

A legal advisor is not a part of this medical board, as the board's purpose is to provide medical, not legal, expertise. The fourth member is often a specialist relevant to the detected anomaly rather than a legal professional.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiologist: Included to assess fetal abnormalities through imaging and provide critical information about the anomaly.

 

Option B. Gynecologist: A core member who handles the MTP procedure and provides obstetric and gynecological care.

 

Option D. Pediatrician: Included to give an opinion on the implications of fetal anomalies and expected postnatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP cases beyond 24 weeks, the medical board consists of medical professionals such as radiologists, gynecologists, and pediatricians, but not legal advisors.

questions.text: Which biological method will you use to control mosquito larvae? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gambusia fish

 

The biological method for controlling mosquito larvae involves the use of larvivorous fishes, such as Gambusia, Poecilia, and Labister. These fish species feed on mosquito larvae, helping to control their population.

 

Note - Antilarval chemical method – Paris green (stomach poison)

 

Methods like spraying (insecticides – DDT, pyrethrum, malathion) and distributing nets are measures to control adult mosquitoes but not the larvae stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDT Spray 3 times a month - This option is incorrect because spraying is a chemical method used to control adult mosquitoes, not the larvae stage.

 

Option B. Distribute nets - This option is incorrect because mosquito nets are a physical barrier used to prevent adult mosquitoes from biting, but they do not control the larvae stage.

 

Option D. Pyrethrum spray - This option is incorrect because pyrethrum spray is a chemical method used to control adult mosquitoes, not the larvae stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The biological method for controlling mosquito larvae involves the use of larvivorous fish species, such as Gambusia, which feed on and help to control the population of mosquito larvae in their aquatic habitats.

questions.text: A farmer is on a maize-based diet and develops skin rashes on the face, neck, and hand. Which of the following should be given? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The farmer’s symptoms of skin rashes in sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, and hands are characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize-based diets are deficient in tryptophan, which is necessary for niacin synthesis in the body. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, with the dermatitis presenting as symmetrical, pigmented, and scaly skin rashes. Providing niacin supplementation is the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not pellagra. The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurological and cardiovascular, not dermatological.

 

Option C. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency leads to visual problems, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, and does not cause skin rashes typical of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to anemia and neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. It does not cause skin rashes or dermatitis associated with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency in individuals consuming a maize-based diet can lead to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Niacin supplementation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wire Speculum

 

The instrument shown in the image is a wire speculum. It is characterized by its wire-like structure with two loops at the ends and a central hinge mechanism. Wire specula are commonly used in ophthalmic surgeries such as cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery, and pterygium surgery. Their primary function is to keep the eyelids apart, providing clear access to the eye during procedures. The surgeon squeezes the instrument to open it, places it between the eyelids, and then releases it to hold the lids open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lid Clamp:  Incorrect. A lid clamp has a different structure, typically with flat surfaces for gripping the eyelid during lid surgeries like entropion or ectropion repairs.
 

 

Option C. Lid Retractor: Incorrect. A lid retractor usually has a plate-like structure at the front and a handle, used for procedures requiring broader lid retraction.

 

 

Option D. Cat's Paw Retractor: Incorrect. This instrument has a fork-like structure at the end and is commonly used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wire speculum is a key instrument in ophthalmic surgery, used to keep the eyelids open and provide access to the eye during various procedures. Its characteristic wire-like structure with loops at the ends distinguishes it from other lid manipulation instruments.

questions.text: Preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venous

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is a venous sample. Venous blood glucose measurements are considered accurate and reliable for diagnostic purposes. This method is used in clinical settings to ensure consistent and precise glucose level readings. Venous samples are obtained by drawing blood from a vein, typically using a standard venipuncture technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial: Arterial blood samples are primarily used for blood gas analysis rather than for routine glucose testing. Arterial sampling is more invasive and not typically used for random blood sugar testing.

 

Option C. Capillary: Capillary blood samples are commonly used in self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) using finger-prick devices. While convenient for personal use, they are less accurate compared to venous samples and are not typically used in clinical settings for diagnostic purposes.

 

Option D. Arteriole: Arteriole samples are not used for glucose testing. This is a dummy choice, as obtaining blood from arterioles is not a standard practice for measuring blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar in a clinical setting is a venous blood sample due to its accuracy and reliability.

questions.text: In a drowning case, primary relaxation is seen in all muscles except one group of muscles. What is this condition known as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cadaveric spasm

 

Typically, after death, there is a phase of primary relaxation in all muscles, followed by the onset of rigor mortis (stiffening of muscles). This primary relaxation phase usually lasts for about two hours. However, in certain cases, such as intense emotional or physical stress before death, cadaveric spasm can occur.

 

Cadaveric spasm, also known as instantaneous rigor, occurs immediately after death without any preceding relaxation phase. This condition is most commonly seen in the muscles of the hands and forearms. In the context of drowning, the hands may grasp objects such as grass or mud, reflecting the struggle for survival, and these objects may still be clutched post-mortem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs several hours after death, following a period of primary relaxation. It affects all muscles sequentially and is not specific to any particular group of muscles immediately post-death.

 

Option C. Pugilistic attitude: The pugilistic attitude is a posture that results from the coagulation and contraction of muscles due to exposure to intense heat, such as in fire victims. It resembles a boxer's stance and is unrelated to drowning or primary muscle relaxation.

 

Option D. Washerwoman hand: Washerwoman hand refers to the wrinkling of the skin on the hands and feet after prolonged immersion in water. It is not related to muscle relaxation or contraction but rather to skin changes due to water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm occurs immediately after death without a phase of relaxation and is typically seen in the muscles of the hands, often indicating a struggle before death.

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heart disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery. In fact, NVD is preferred in heart disease patients. The second stage of labour is cut short with the use of instrumental vaginal delivery like forceps or ventouse assisted vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic tumor: Pelvic tumor if diagnosed may interfere with normal labor and needs to be evaluated before deciding the mode of delivery

 

Option B. Herpes infection:  Active herpes is an absolute contra-indication to a normal delivery due to the high viral shedding in the lesions and increased risk of neonatal herpes.

 

Option D. History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies: History of 2 or more previous cesareans is also a contra-indication to a vaginal delivery and hence induction is not done

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery, and NVD is preferred in heart disease patients.

 

Ref: Page no 332, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A patient had enlarging nodules present on his scalp. He was taking prednisolone, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus. His clinical lesion and the histopathological lesion are shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malakoplakia

 

The patient's clinical history and biopsy findings suggest a diagnosis of Malakoplakia. Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition that is often associated with immunosuppressive states, such as in patients taking medications like prednisolone, mycophenolate, and tacrolimus.

 

The characteristic histopathological feature of Malakoplakia is the presence of Michaelis-Guttmann bodies, which are basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions with a "targetoid" appearance seen in macrophages.

 

These bodies result from incomplete phagocytosis and subsequent calcium and iron deposition.

 

Malakoplakia commonly affects the urinary bladder but can also present in other organs, including the skin, as seen in this patient with scalp lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis would typically present with caseating granulomas, which are not seen in the provided histopathological image. The characteristic Michaelis-Guttmann bodies in this image rule out tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Pyoderma gangrenosum: This condition is usually associated with painful ulcerative skin lesions and does not present with the histopathological findings seen here. Pyoderma gangrenosum is not associated with Michaelis-Guttmann bodies.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lesion: Drug-induced skin lesions generally present with nonspecific inflammation or necrosis rather than granulomatous inflammation with the distinct Michaelis-Guttmann bodies characteristic of Malakoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition marked by Michaelis-Guttmann bodies and is often seen in immunosuppressed patients. It can affect organs beyond the urinary bladder, including the skin.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension. He has a history of renal stones and has experienced a few episodes of renal colic. Which diuretic is the most appropriate to use? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that decreases calcium excretion in the urine by promoting calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. This mechanism reduces the amount of calcium that is excreted into the urine, which lowers the risk of renal stone formation. Although thiazides can cause hypercalcemia by increasing calcium levels in the blood, they are beneficial in patients with a history of renal stones because they reduce urinary calcium levels, thereby decreasing the likelihood of stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases calcium excretion in the urine by inhibiting calcium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This can lead to increased calcium in the urine, which raises the risk of renal stone formation, making it less appropriate for patients with a history of renal stones.

 

Option C. Ethacrynic acid: Similar to furosemide, ethacrynic acid is a loop diuretic that increases calcium excretion in the urine. Its use can also increase the risk of renal stones and is not the best choice for patients with a history of nephrolithiasis.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works primarily by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron, leading to the retention of potassium and excretion of sodium. It does not have a significant impact on calcium excretion and is not indicated for reducing the risk of renal stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is the preferred diuretic in patients with a history of renal stones because it reduces urinary calcium excretion, thereby decreasing the risk of stone formation.

questions.text: Which of these is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradycardia

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate (tachycardia) and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Signs of Cocaine intoxication:

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Myocardial ischemia: Cocaine can induce myocardial ischemia due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties on coronary arteries.

 

Option C. Hyperthermia: Hyperthermia is a common symptom of cocaine intoxication due to increased metabolic activity and muscle activity.

 

Option D. Agitation: Agitation is a well-known effect of cocaine's stimulant properties on the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine poisoning typically causes increased heart rate (tachycardia) rather than bradycardia, along with other symptoms like myocardial ischemia, hyperthermia, and agitation.

choices.text: Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

questions.text: A 57-year-old person completed his treatment of leprosy. Two years later, he presents with a punched-out painless ulcer on his sole. What is the next best step in the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

 

The patient is presenting with a chronic trophic ulcer, which is a common complication in patients with leprosy, particularly after the disease has been treated and the bacteria eradicated.

 

Trophic ulcers arise due to the loss of sensation (neuropathy) and autonomic disturbances leading to dry, cracked skin that is prone to injury. The patient does not feel pain, which allows the ulcer to become large and deep over time.

 

The correct management involves reducing pressure on the affected area to allow healing. This can be achieved by advising the patient to bear less weight on the affected foot and using a plaster cast or a total contact cast, which redistributes weight and protects the ulcer from further trauma.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Plantar ulceration is a common complication in lepromatous leprosy, often occurring even after the disease is arrested. Progressive fibrosis of nerves leads to 'glove and stocking' anesthesia, with loss of sensation in the limbs, particularly the plantar aspect of the foot.
  • This condition is one of the most frequent impairments in leprosy, reported in 21% to 63% of newly reported cases. The combination of loss of touch and pain, along with foot deformity, causes disproportionate weight distribution on the sole of the foot, leading to non-healing or chronic ulceration.
  • Types:
    • Acute ulcers: Present with acute infection and severe acute inflammation.
    • Chronic ulcers: Long-standing ulcers without signs of acute inflammation.
    • Complicated chronic ulcers: These ulcers result from the spread of infection to deeper structures like the underlying bone, joint, or tendon sheath.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restart MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy is used to treat active infections caused by Mycobacterium leprae. However, in this case, the patient has completed treatment, and the ulcer is due to neuropathy, not an active infection. Therefore, restarting MDT is not necessary and would not address the ulcer.

 

Option C. Aggressive Debridement with IV antibiotics: Aggressive debridement and IV antibiotics are typically indicated for infected ulcers or those with acute signs of inflammation. In this case, the ulcer is chronic and not primarily due to infection, so this approach is not warranted.

 

Option D. Amputation: Amputation is a last resort, reserved for cases where ulcers have led to severe, life-threatening complications such as osteomyelitis that cannot be managed by other means. This is not the case here, and such an extreme measure is not necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of chronic trophic ulcers in leprosy, reducing pressure on the ulcerated area through weight redistribution, such as with a plaster cast, is essential to promote healing and prevent further complication

choices.text: 4 years
7 years
9 years

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 13 years

 

The X-ray image shows:

 

  • All carpal bones are developed. This implies age is > 10 years. Pisiform is the last bone to appear which is visible and can be easily identified as marked below:

 

 

  • Base of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft (It fuses at 15-17 years age). This implies age is < 17 years.

 

Hence, age is 10-17 years. So, the best answer here is 13 years.

 

Educational Objective

 

Age of appearance of carpal bones is given below:

choices.text: Positive feedback
Negative feedback
Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Explanation

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves →nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feedforward: Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.

 

Option D. Adaptive control regulation: Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

questions.text: Septal perforation caused due to surgery of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SMR (Submucous Resection)

  

Septal perforation is more commonly associated with SMR (Submucous Resection) than with septoplasty. In SMR, the deviated part of the septum, which includes both the bony and cartilaginous components, is removed. This removal can lead to the loss of structural support from the cartilage or bone. If there is any tear in the mucosal flaps that cover the septum, it may fail to heal properly due to the absence of underlying support, leading to a septal perforation.

 

During SMR, the absence of this central support structure means that even a minor mucosal tear can result in a perforation because the mucosal flaps on either side of the septum may fuse incorrectly, creating a hole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): FESS is a procedure focused on the sinuses and not the septum itself, thus it does not typically result in septal perforation. This surgery involves the removal of sinus tissue and does not interfere with the septal structure.

 

Option C. Septoplasty: In septoplasty, the septum is straightened by removing or reshaping the cartilage and bone but importantly, the removed parts are replaced back between the mucosal flaps. This restoration of structure reduces the likelihood of perforations because the mucosal layers are supported by the replaced bone or cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal perforation is a recognized complication of SMR due to the complete removal of septal cartilage and bone without replacement, which can lead to mucosal tears and eventual perforation if the layers do not heal correctly.

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest X-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta, which causes an obstruction to blood flow. This condition leads to high blood pressure in the arteries that are proximal to the narrowing (upper limbs) and lower blood pressure in the arteries distal to the narrowing (lower limbs).

 

The key findings in this scenario include:

 

  • Feeble femoral pulses: Due to reduced blood flow past the coarctation.
  • Upper limb hypertension: Caused by increased resistance proximal to the coarctation.
  • Chest X-ray showing enlarged intercostal arteries: These develop as collateral circulation to bypass the coarctation, which can cause rib notching seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the septum between the heart's atria. It typically causes a left-to-right shunt and can lead to increased pulmonary blood flow and right heart overload. It does not cause differential blood pressure between limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option C. Bicuspid aortic valve: A bicuspid aortic valve is a congenital valve anomaly that can lead to aortic stenosis or regurgitation but does not typically cause differential blood pressure between the limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA is a persistent opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. It causes a continuous murmur and can lead to heart failure if significant but does not cause differential blood pressure or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in patients with a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, feeble femoral pulses, and chest X-ray findings of enlarged intercostal arteries, indicating collateral circulation.

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

 

In a patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the immediate management involves FLIP Therapy (fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy and Potassium management). This patient's blood glucose is significantly elevated, and the presence of ketones indicates DKA, which is a medical emergency.

 

1. Fluids: The initial step is to administer intravenous (IV) fluids to correct dehydration and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. The typical approach involves giving isotonic saline (0.9% sodium chloride) at a rate of 10-20 mL/kg/hr (2-3L) for the first 2-3 hours. This helps to correct hypovolemia, improve perfusion, and begin to lower blood glucose levels.

 

Criteria for fluid management: After the initial two to three hours of treatment, switch from initial fluids (typically normal saline) to half normal saline for ongoing maintenance. If capillary blood glucose (CBG) drops below 300 mg/dL, and specifically if it falls below 250 mg/dL, add 5% dextrose water to the regimen. The purpose of adding dextrose is to maintain a target CBG range of 200 to 300 mg/dL. This range helps prevent hypoglycemia, which is a critical concern in the management process.

 

2. Insulin: Insulin therapy is crucial to halt ketogenesis and reduce blood glucose levels. After 1 hr of fluid start insulin. The recommended protocol for DKA involves IV regular insulin because of its rapid onset and short duration of action. The insulin regimen follows a fixed dose insulin infusion (FDII) approach. This helps to normalize blood glucose and ketone levels efficiently.

 

First option: Continuous infusion at 0.15 units/kg/hour.

 

Second option (more commonly used): Administer a 0.1 units/kg bolus, followed by a 0.1 units/kg/hour infusion.

 

IV regular insulin is preferred over subcutaneous (SC) insulin in emergency settings like DKA due to its predictable absorption and ability to be titrated easily based on frequent blood glucose monitoring.

 

Adjustments Based on Blood Glucose Levels: Monitor capillary blood glucose (CBG). If CBG drops below 300 mg/dL, reduce the insulin infusion to half the dose (0.05 units/kg/hour).

 

Criteria for Stopping Insulin Infusion: Insulin infusion can be stopped ONLY when the patient tolerates oral feeds without vomiting or abdominal pain. Other criteria include resolution of ketoacidosis, negative or trace positive plasma ketones, and an anion gap less than 12, pH more than 7.3 and serum bicarbonate more than 18. Transition to subcutaneous insulin upon meeting these criteria.

 

Potassium Management: Potassium addition is tailored based on serum potassium levels. When serum potassium levels are within a normal range, add approximately 40 milliequivalents of potassium chloride (KCL) per liter of IV fluid administered. This ensures adequate potassium levels to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Monitoring

 

  • If serum potassium is below 3.3, administer IV potassium chloride (KCL) before insulin to prevent hypokalemia-induced arrhythmias.
  • If serum potassium is between 3.3 and 5.2, administer insulin and KCL together.
  • If serum potassium exceeds 5.3 & above, administer insulin without KCL and monitor serum potassium closely.

 

Treatment Goals and Precautions:

 

  • Aim for a target CBG of 200 to 300 mg/dL to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • The common causes of death in patients with DKA, particularly during the treatment phase – 
    • Cerebral edema (MC) may occur due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose levels, which can lead to an osmotic shift. This shift causes fluids to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) to the intracellular fluid (ICF), resulting in swelling of the brain tissue.
    • 2nd MC cause is Potassium Disorder esp. Hypokalemia, this can result in ventricular arrythmias.
    • Other causes include ARDS, patients can initially develop acute kidney injury (pre-renal), later if severe, leads to ATN (Acute tubular necrosis) due to hypoperfusion of kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is not suitable for acute management due to its prolonged action and delayed onset, making it inappropriate for rapid correction of hyperglycemia and ketonemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin: While regular insulin is appropriate, the subcutaneous route is less effective in severe DKA where IV administration allows for better control and titration.

 

Option C. Intravenous insulin I.V. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is never administered IV due to the risk of prolonged hypoglycemia and lack of titratability. It is also not designed for acute management settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

choices.text: Paralysis lasting more than 1 to 3 hours

questions.text: In a patient with a normal quantity of pseudocholinesterase and a dibucaine number of 50, what is the likely duration of paralysis following a 1 mg/kg dose of intravenous succinylcholine? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paralysis lasting 20 to 30 minutes

 

A dibucaine number of 50% indicates a heterozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme. While normal individuals (dibucaine number ~80%) metabolize succinylcholine rapidly with paralysis lasting 9-14 minutes, patients with heterozygous atypical enzyme (dibucaine number around 50%) experience intermediate prolongation of neuromuscular blockade. This intermediate enzyme activity results in paralysis lasting approximately 20-30 minutes - longer than normal but not as prolonged as in homozygous atypical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperkalemic cardiac arrest:  This is a potential complication of succinylcholine in patients with denervation, burns, or muscular dystrophies, but is not directly related to pseudocholinesterase activity or dibucaine number.

 

Option B. Paralysis lasting 5 to 10 minutes: This represents the normal duration of action for succinylcholine in patients with normal pseudocholinesterase activity and normal dibucaine number (~80%). The patient with a Dibucine number of 50% will have a longer duration.

 

Option D. Paralysis lasting more than 1 to 3 hours: This extremely prolonged duration would be seen in homozygous atypical patients with dibucaine numbers around 20%. Since our patient has an intermediate dibucaine number of 50%, the paralysis will be intermediate in duration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A dibucaine number of 50% indicates heterozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase with intermediate enzyme activity, resulting in paralysis lasting 20-30 minutes following succinylcholine administration - longer than normal but not as severely prolonged as in homozygous atypical cases.

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes USG examination. She is found to have twins, but one-month age gap in twins on USG scan. What is this phenomenon called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superfetation

 

Superfetation is a rare phenomenon where a second pregnancy occurs while a woman is already pregnant, resulting in twins with different ages. This happens due to two separate acts of intercourse occurring in two different menstrual cycles, leading to two embryos of different gestational ages. In superfetation, one baby is conceived during one cycle, and another baby is conceived in a subsequent cycle, often resulting in a noticeable size difference between the two babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superfecundation: Superfecundation also involves twins and separate acts of intercourse; however, it occurs within the same menstrual cycle. This means that two ova are fertilized at or near the same time, leading to twins of the same gestational age and size. Unlike superfetation, the twins are conceived during the same cycle.

 

Option C. Illegitimate child: This term refers to a child born outside of marriage and is not related to the phenomenon of having twins with different ages. It does not describe a medical condition or scenario of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Suppositious child: This term generally refers to a child that is wrongly supposed or believed to belong to a particular family. It is not relevant to the context of twins with a one-month age gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfetation is characterized by the occurrence of two separate pregnancies in different menstrual cycles, leading to twins of different gestational ages.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below in a patient who presented with a history of fall. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior shoulder dislocation 

 

  • Anterior shoulder dislocation is the commonest type of dislocation and usually results from forced abduction, external rotation and extension of the shoulder. 
  • The more prevalent age group are young adult men who sustained high-energy injuries to the shoulder. 
  • On physical examination, the arm is abducted and externally rotated.
  • There is "squaring" of the shoulder i.e., loss of rounded appearance of the humeral head, and sharp prominence of the acromion ("squaring"). 
  • Due to axillary nerve neuropraxia, there can be reduced sensation over the lateral side of the shoulder. 
  • Radiograph shows the humeral head displaced medially and overlies the glenoid. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior shoulder dislocation: Posterior dislocation of shoulder takes place when the trauma occur with the arm in a flexed, adducted, and internally rotated position. The patient presents with limited external rotation, shoulder locked in internal rotation, and pain on flexion, adduction and internal rotation of the shoulder. Radiograph may show a 'lightbulb' sign on AP view. Axillary lateral view X-ray is the best view to demonstrate dislocation. 

 

 

Option C. Intrathoracic dislocation of shoulder: An intrathoracic shoulder dislocation is a rare injury, usually the result of high-energy trauma. It often occurs in conjunction with thoracic, pelvic, and long bone injuries. In addition, there is often significant injuries to the shoulder girdle and chest wall associated with neurovascular compromise. The shoulder is forced into a position of abduction and external rotation, combined with a compressive force. The patient may present with severe pain in the shoulder and chest area, difficulty breathing, swelling and bruising in the chest and shoulder, limited or no movement in the affected arm. 

 

 

Option D. Subglenoid dislocation of shoulder: Subglenoid shoulder dislocation is a type of anterior shoulder dislocation where the head of the humerus is displaced in front of the glenoid cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the anterior dislocation of the shoulder. 
  • In the given X-ray, the humerus head is down and out i.e., it lies beneath the glenoid cavity and the arm is abducted. 
  • In the posterior dislocation, on x-ray, the humeral head is up and in i.e., lying above the glenoid with the arm adducted.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
