  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

questions.text: The Hunterian ligature operation is performed for? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aneurysm

 

Explanation:

 

The Hunterian ligature operation refers to proximal ligation of the feeding artery to treat an aneurysm. This surgical technique was pioneered by John Hunter, who recognized that ligating the artery proximal to the aneurysm could reduce blood flow into the aneurysmal sac, allowing it to thrombose and potentially shrink over time. This approach avoids direct manipulation of the aneurysm sac, which historically was a riskier procedure before modern vascular techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Varicose veins Incorrect. The surgical management for varicose veins includes techniques like Trendelenburg operation (flush ligation of great saphenous vein at saphenofemoral junction), stripping, EVLA (Endovenous Laser Ablation), RFA (Radiofrequency Ablation), foam sclerotherapy, and SEPS (Subfascial Endoscopic Perforator Surgery). Hunterian ligation is not used for varicose veins.

 

Option B: Arteriovenous fistulae Incorrect. Management of arteriovenous fistulae typically involves embolization techniques. Simple ligation of the feeding artery alone is specifically mentioned as being "of no lasting value and is actually detrimental as it may preclude treatment by embolisation."

 

Option D: Acute ischemia Incorrect. Acute limb ischemia requires restoration of blood flow, not interruption of it. Treatment involves emergency embolectomy or thrombectomy (using Fogarty balloon catheter), not arterial ligation which would worsen ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hunterian ligature operation involves proximal ligation of the feeding artery to an aneurysm to reduce flow and promote thrombosis of the aneurysmal sac - representing one of the earliest surgical approaches to aneurysm management before modern vascular reconstruction techniques.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for delusional disorder?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Young age

 

This is not a typical risk factor for delusional disorder. It usually starts in middle or late adult life.

 

Other Options:

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle or late adult life, and it is uncommon in young individuals.

 

Option A. Recent immigration: True. Recent immigration or cultural isolation can be associated with the development of certain types of delusions.

 

Option B. Social isolation: True. Individuals who are socially isolated are at increased risk for the development of delusional disorder.

 

Option C. Family history: True. Having a family history of delusional disorder can increase the risk of developing the condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle to late adulthood. It is characterized by development of a single delusion or a set of related delusions, which are usually persistent and sometimes are life long.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 331.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known allergy to penicillin presents with a enterococcal endocarditis. The physician needs to prescribe an antibiotic but wants to ensure it is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy. The patient has had previous allergic reactions to penicillin, including rash and swelling. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in a patient allergic to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

  • The clinical scenario involves a 45-year-old patient with enterococcal endocarditis and a known allergy to penicillin, presenting with previous allergic reactions including rash and swelling. 
  • The physician needs to choose an antibiotic that is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy as well as effective for enterococcal endocarditis. Let's review the options:
  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is not related to penicillin. 
  • It is safe for patients with penicillin allergies and is commonly used to treat gram-positive infections, including those caused by enterococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is generally considered safe for patients with penicillin allergies because it does not share the beta-lactam ring structure of penicillins, which is typically responsible for allergic reactions. However, aztreonam is effective only against gram negative bacteria and is not suitable for enterococcal infections which is a gram positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin. Although cephalosporins have a beta-lactam ring similar to penicillins, the rate of cross-reactivity is relatively low, especially with third-generation cephalosporins. However, caution is advised in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a penicillin derivative and should be avoided in patients with penicillin allergies due to the high risk of cross-reactivity and potential for severe allergic reactions.

 

Conclusion

 

The safest options for a patient with a penicillin allergy are:

 

Aztreonam (Option a)

 

Vancomycin (Option b)

 

Given the specific need to avoid penicillin and its derivatives and to treat gram positive (enterococcal) infections, Vancomycin is a safe and effective choice for treating enterococcal endocarditis in this patient. Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

b. Vancomycin
